conclusion: Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction is used to determine the induced EMF in a coil.
Faraday's law states that the induced EMF in a coil is given by the formula: \( \mathcal{E} = -n \frac{d\Phi}{dt} \).
\( n \) is the number of turns in the coil, \( \Phi \) is the magnetic flux through the coil, and \( t \) is time.
The magnetic flux \( \Phi \) through the coil is given by \( \Phi = B \cdot A \cdot \cos(\theta) \).

\( B \) is the magnetic field strength, \( A \) is the area of the coil perpendicular to the magnetic field, \( \theta \) is the angle between the normal to the coil and the direction of the magnetic field.
For a rectangular coil rotating about its symmetry axis, the angle \( \theta \) changes with time as the coil rotates.
The area \( A \) of the coil is calculated as \( A = l_{AB} \cdot l_{BC} = 0.2 \, \text{m} \times 0.5 \, \text{m} = 0.1 \, \text{m}^2 \).
The magnetic field \( B \) is constant at \( 0.1 \, \text{T} \).
The angular velocity \( \omega \) is given as \( 100\pi \, \text{rad/s} \).
The rate of change of the magnetic flux \( \frac{d\Phi}{dt} \) is derived as \( \frac{d\Phi}{dt} = B \cdot A \cdot \frac{d}{dt} \left( \cos(\theta) \right) \).
The rate of change of magnetic flux is \( \frac{d\Phi}{dt} = B \cdot A \cdot (-\sin(\theta)) \cdot \omega = -B \cdot A \cdot \omega \cdot \sin(\omega t) \).
The induced EMF \( \mathcal{E} \) is \( \mathcal{E} = -n \cdot B \cdot A \cdot \omega \cdot \sin(\omega t) \).
The magnitude of the induced EMF is \( |\mathcal{E}| = n \cdot B \cdot A \cdot \omega \cdot |\sin(\omega t)| \).
